name: Financial Management
description: Budgeting, Audits, Sanctions, Procurement, and Financial Control in Public Service.

subcategories.name: Budgeting
subcategories.description: Appropriation Act, warrants, virement, budget cycles, MTEF, and emoluments.

questions.question: The payment of emoluments and wages to public servants is primarily guided by which document, as referenced in the Public Service Rules (PSR)?
questions.explanation: Financial Regulations contain guidance on the payment of emoluments and wages [1]. Rule 040101 confirms that the FR governs the payment process [1, 2].

questions.question: The legal instrument enacted by the National Assembly that authorizes the Federal Government to withdraw funds from the Consolidated Revenue Fund (CRF) for annual expenditure is the:
questions.explanation: The Annual Appropriation Act, enacted by the National Assembly, is the legal instrument that authorizes the Federal Government to withdraw funds from the CRF for annual expenditure [3].

questions.question: How often must the Vote Book be updated to accurately reflect budget implementation and commitments, ensuring effective expenditure control?
questions.explanation: Vote books should be updated daily to reflect accurate budget implementation and commitments [4].

questions.question: What is the technical term for the authorized transfer of funds from one specified budget subhead to another within the same expenditure vote?
questions.explanation: Virement is the authorized transfer of funds from one sub-head to another within the same head of expenditure [5, 6].

questions.question: Any request for the legal movement of funds between budget subheads (Virement) must be formally backed by:
questions.explanation: Virement must be formally approved and backed by a Virement Warrant [7].

questions.question: Expenditure incurred by an MDA that exceeds the amount appropriated for that specific subhead without subsequent legislative sanction is termed:
questions.explanation: Spending that surpasses the approved budget is classified as an Excess Vote or unauthorized expenditure [7].

questions.question: At the end of the fiscal year, all unspent budget balances must generally be:
options: Carried forward to the next year.
Returned to the Treasury (Consolidated Revenue Fund).
questions.explanation: At the close of the fiscal year, unspent budget balances are typically returned to the Treasury, specifically the CRF [8].

questions.question: Which official document is used to request for the release of funds from the Treasury to the MDAs for execution of both capital and recurrent projects?
questions.explanation: A Warrant provides for the release of funds for both capital and recurrent expenditures [8].

questions.question: What is the consequence of incurring expenditure far exceeding appropriation that requires subsequent legislative action via a supplementary budget?
options: A monetary fine on the Accounting Officer.
A formal query from the Auditor-General for unauthorized spending.
Immediate dismissal of the Vote Controller.
questions.explanation: Excess spending constitutes unauthorized expenditure and is reported by the Auditor-General, leading to legislative examination [9].

questions.question: What must be checked in the **Vote Book** immediately before any commitment (like issuing an LPO) is made?
options: The date the last Virement Warrant was issued.
The balance remaining in the relevant subhead.
The date of the last audit query.
questions.explanation: Before issuing any commitment, the Vote book balance must be checked to confirm that the expenditure is within approved limits [10].

questions.question: The **Medium-Term Expenditure Framework (MTEF)**, a key planning tool, requires government budgeting to focus on planning and projections over a rolling period of:
questions.explanation: The MTEF sets out government‚Äôs spending priorities and projections over a three-year period [11].

questions.question: The payment of promotion arrears to an officer shall be made within the year the promotion is effected, calculated from the:
options: Date of receiving the promotion letter.
Date the officer assumes duty in the new post.
Effective date of the promotion (1st January of the year).
questions.explanation: Payment of promotion arrears shall be made within the year the promotion is effected, calculated from the effective date of the promotion (Rule 040104(iii)) [11, 12].

questions.question: An officer, upon first appointment, shall be eligible for emoluments as from the date of:
questions.explanation: Rule 040102 confirms that on first appointment, emoluments shall, as a general rule, be paid as from the date of assumption of duty [12, 13].

questions.question: All newly employed Officers must be placed on the **IPPIS platform** within a maximum period of:
options: Two months of assumption of duty.
questions.explanation: All Officers shall be placed on the IPPIS platform within two months of assumption of duty (Rule 040102) [13, 14].

questions.question: Funding used to acquire or maintain fixed assets that benefit future fiscal periods is classified as:
questions.explanation: Capital Expenditure refers to funding used to acquire or maintain fixed assets that benefit future fiscal periods [15].

questions.question: Which officer is primarily responsible for maintaining the departmental Vote Ledger (Vote Book), tracking budget allocations, and controlling expenditure commitments?
questions.explanation: The Vote Controller maintains the Vote Book (also referred to as the departmental vote ledger) to monitor budgetary allocations and expenditures [16, 17].

questions.question: Who is responsible for preparing departmental financial statements at the end of the fiscal year?
questions.explanation: The Head of Accounts prepares departmental financial statements at the end of the fiscal year [18].

questions.question: Which officer must sign all Payment Vouchers before payments are processed, confirming the correctness and classification of the transaction?
questions.explanation: The Head of Accounts must sign all payment vouchers before payments are processed [19].

questions.question: The primary responsibility of the Permanent Secretary/CEO as the Chief Accounting Officer is:
options: To manage the MDA's budget, expenditure, and compliance with Financial Regulations.
To approve all staff annual leave.
questions.explanation: The Permanent Secretary/CEO, as Accounting Officer, is responsible for financial management, expenditure, and adherence to Financial Regulations [19, 20].

questions.question: What does the term **‚ÄúBudget‚Äù** primarily represent?
options: Detailed estimates of government revenue and expenditure for a fiscal year.
A legal document setting out procurement rules.
The annual report on financial performance.
questions.explanation: The Budget shows detailed estimates of government revenue and expenditure for a fiscal year [21].

questions.question: An Officer's increment is typically withheld or deferred on grounds of unsatisfactory performance, or when the officer is under:
options: External training longer than six months.
questions.explanation: An Officer on an incremental grade level shall normally be granted an increment unless he is on interdiction/suspension or has a disciplinary action pending (Rule 040202) [22].

questions.question: What is the standard incremental date for an Officer appointed or promoted to a post in the Federal Public Service?
options: The 1st January of the year following at least six months of service or promotion.
The end of the current quarter.
The 31st December of the current year.
questions.explanation: The incremental date of an Officer appointed or promoted to a post in the Federal Public Service shall be 1st January of the year following at least six months of service or promotion (Rule 040203) [23].

questions.question: A staff on transfer shall be eligible for the emolument attached to his new office with effect from the date he:
options: Assumes duty in the new office.
questions.explanation: A staff on transfer shall be eligible for the emolument attached to his new office with effect from the date he assumes duty (Rule 040103) [24-26].

questions.question: If an Officer is promoted to a grade level that does NOT overlap his old grade level, he shall be placed at the:
options: Mid-point of the new grade level.
Minimum point of his new salary grade level.
Maximum point of the old grade level.
Next step above his previous salary.
questions.explanation: If the Officer is promoted to a grade level that does not overlap his old grade level, he shall be placed at the minimum point of his new salary grade level (Rule 040104(i)) [24, 27].

questions.question: The overall budget proposal for the Federal Government is prepared by which body?
questions.explanation: The Budget Office of the Federation, under the Ministry of Finance, prepares the federal budget proposal [28].

questions.question: What document accompanies all government payments made in Ministries, detailing the expenditure, head, subhead, and required authorization?
questions.explanation: All government payments must be backed by duly approved Payment Vouchers [29].

questions.question: Who, as the Head of Department, must certify payments by confirming that services have been duly performed before payment is made to a contractor or service provider?
questions.explanation: The Head of Department certifies that services have been duly performed before payments are made [30, 31].

questions.question: What financial status occurs when government expenditure exceeds its revenue within a specific fiscal period?
questions.explanation: A budget deficit occurs when expenditure exceeds revenue [32].

questions.question: What document is used to track all outstanding cash advances issued to staff and contractors against the budget?
questions.explanation: The Advance Ledger is specifically maintained to record all outstanding advances to staff and contractors, ensuring recovery and control [33].

questions.question: The total amount of funds allocated for staff salaries (Personnel Emoluments) in the budget is controlled primarily by data sourced from which platform?
questions.explanation: The Integrated Personnel and Payroll Information System (IPPIS) holds the accurate data on staff nominal roll, grade levels, and steps, which determines personnel emoluments [34-36].

questions.question: The primary objective of recording all financial commitments in the Vote Book (Obligation Control) is to:
options: Ensure that all planned expenditure is within the legal capacity of the approved budget.
questions.explanation: The Vote Book ensures that expenditure is kept within budget limits [36, 37].

questions.question: Which MDA classification is authorized to manage its financial records internally but must still comply with FR and submit statutory returns to the OAGF?
questions.explanation: Self-Accounting MDAs are authorized to manage their financial records internally but must still comply with FR and submit statutory returns [38].

questions.question: The fund established for the replacement of depreciating government assets is the:
questions.explanation: The Replacement Reserve Fund is used for replacing depreciating government assets [39-41].

questions.question: If an officer's increment is deferred due to unsatisfactory performance, the deferment must be fixed for a minimum period of:
questions.explanation: If an increment is deferred, the period must be fixed for not less than six months (Rule 040205) [42].

questions.question: Decisions on deferment or withholding of increment and stoppage of salaries must be communicated to the officer concerned and simultaneously to:
options: The Office of the Accountant General of the Federation, the Office of the Auditor General for the Federation, and the OHCSF.
questions.explanation: Rule 040209 mandates communication of increment decisions to the officer and simultaneously to the OAGF, OAuGF, and OHCSF [43-45].

questions.question: If an officer's salary is withheld due to unauthorized absence from duty, the sanction is governed by:
questions.explanation: Rule 040206 allows salary to be withheld in cases of unauthorized absence (Loss of Pay) [46, 47].

questions.question: In budget terms, what is the specific classification of government spending on assets and infrastructure that create future benefits?
questions.explanation: Capital expenditure refers to government spending on assets and infrastructure that create future benefits [48].

questions.question: The **Government Integrated Financial Management Information System (GIFMIS)** supports the budgeting process by providing:
options: A platform for political campaign financing.
Integrated financial operations, accounting, and expenditure tracking.
The exclusive mechanism for collecting tax revenue.
A register of physical assets only.
questions.explanation: GIFMIS supports real-time public finance tracking, integrating budgeting, accounting, and expenditure [49].

questions.question: If an officer is promoted across overlapping salary levels, the placement rule dictates the officer is placed at the:
options: Maximum point of the new grade.
Minimum point of the new grade.
Next salary point above previous earnings.
questions.explanation: If the emolument in the former post is higher than the minimum point of the new salary grade level, the officer will be placed on the next point, higher than their former emolument (Rule 040104(ii)) [50, 51].

questions.question: Which body prepares Nigeria‚Äôs annual budget performance reports for review?
questions.explanation: The Budget Officer prepares annual budget performance reports for review [52].

questions.question: The **Contingencies Fund** is reserved exclusively for which type of expenditure?
questions.explanation: The Contingencies Fund is used to meet unforeseen and urgent government expenditures [53-55].

questions.question: Who authorizes payments from the Consolidated Revenue Fund (CRF)?
questions.explanation: Payments from the Consolidated Revenue Fund must be authorized by the National Assembly [56].

questions.question: The **Annual Financial Statement** is prepared to report on government's:
options: Financial performance within the fiscal year.
questions.explanation: The Annual Financial Statement reports on government‚Äôs financial performance within the fiscal year [57].

questions.question: If an officer is promoted and the new salary grade level does NOT overlap the old grade level, emolument payment commences at the minimum point of the new grade level, taking effect from:
options: The date of the FCSC approval letter.
The 1st of January of the promotion year.
The date of the promotion interview.
The date the officer assumes the new post.
questions.explanation: The payment of emoluments on promotion arrears is calculated from the effective date of promotion, typically the 1st of January of the promotion year (Rule 040104(iii)) [58].

questions.question: Payment of promotion arrears to an officer shall be made within what timeframe of the promotion being effected?
options: Within the year the promotion is effected.
questions.explanation: Payment of promotion arrears shall be made within the year the promotion is effected (Rule 040104(iii)) [12].

questions.question: Which of the following is defined as the maximum amount an MDA can legally spend within a fiscal year for a defined purpose?
questions.explanation: Appropriation is the legislative authorization for expenditure, defining the maximum legal spending limit [59].

questions.question: The Head of the MDA or Permanent Secretary must ensure that all personnel data entered into IPPIS are accurate and:
options: Verified by the Minister of Finance
questions.explanation: Accurate information is essential for correct payment; the Head of the MDA certifies the records for IPPIS/payroll (Rule 040102) [60].

questions.question: The authority responsible for granting a special increment to mitigate the lasting negative effects of an increment that was previously withheld rests with the:
options: National Salaries, Incomes and Wages Commission (NSIWC)
questions.explanation: The Federal Civil Service Commission is the body empowered to grant special increments (Rule 040207) [61].

questions.question: An officer duly authorized to act in a post is eligible for acting allowance EXCEPT for any days in excess of how many days of continuous absence from duty on account of ill-health?
questions.explanation: Acting allowance is paid except for any days in excess of 14 days of continuous absence from duty on account of ill-health (Rule 140130) [62].

questions.question: Resettlement Allowance shall be paid at the rate of what percentage of an Officer‚Äôs annual total emolument?
options: 1% of the officer‚Äôs annual total emolument
2% of the officer‚Äôs annual total emolument
5% of the officer‚Äôs annual total emolument
10% of the officer‚Äôs annual total emolument
questions.explanation: Resettlement Allowance shall be paid at the rate of 2% of an Officer‚Äôs annual total emolument (Rule 140136) [63, 64].

subcategories.name: Procurement
subcategories.description: Public Procurement Act, due process, thresholds, and procurement regulations

questions.question: The foundational legal framework governing the acquisition of goods, works, and services by all Federal MDAs is the:
questions.explanation: The Public Procurement Act (PPA) 2007 provides the primary legal basis and framework for managing public procurement processes in Nigeria [65, 66].

questions.question: What is the main objective of the Public Procurement Act, 2007?
options: To ensure transparency, fairness, accountability, and value for money.
To fund the Ministry‚Äôs overhead costs.
questions.explanation: The PPA aims to ensure transparency, accountability, and value for money in public procurement [67, 68].

questions.question: Which procurement method is mandated as the default procedure for public procurement under the PPA?
questions.explanation: Open Competitive Bidding is the preferred and default method (Section 24) [69, 70].

questions.question: The procurement plan for an MDA must be based on and aligned with:
options: Historical spending from five years ago.
questions.explanation: Procurement planning must be aligned with appropriated budget provisions to ensure fiscal responsibility and is required under Section 14 [71, 72].

questions.question: What is the mandatory period for the archive retention of procurement records and documents?
questions.explanation: Procurement documents must be retained for at least 5 years to support potential audits and inquiries (Section 34) [73, 74].

questions.question: The mandatory pre-qualification requirement for all bidders includes the submission of a valid:
options: Letter of Recommendation from the Minister.
questions.explanation: One of the essential prequalification requirements is the submission of a Tax Clearance Certificate (TCC), usually covering the preceding three years (Section 16) [73, 75].

questions.question: Which document is mandatory for processing payment to a contractor after goods or services have been received and verified?
questions.explanation: Payment is not processed without the Job Completion Certificate [76, 77], which confirms that work was done or goods were received.

questions.question: Which of the following describes a **Responsive Bid**?
options: A bid that meets all the technical and administrative requirements of the tender document.
A bid submitted by a government official.
The bid with the longest duration.
questions.explanation: A responsive bid is one that complies fully with all criteria stated in the bid document and is eligible for evaluation [78].

questions.question: What is the primary function of **Bid Security** provided by bidders?
options: To serve as a performance bond for the awarded contract.
To ensure commitment and prevent premature withdrawal of the bid.
To cover the cost of bid evaluation.
questions.explanation: Bid security is a financial guarantee that ensures the bidder‚Äôs commitment and discourages frivolous or unserious bidding (Section 28) [79, 80].

questions.question: The principle of **Due Process** in public procurement primarily emphasizes:
options: Rapid contract award regardless of procedure.
Adherence to legal and procedural requirements in awarding contracts.
Maximizing the margin of profit for contractors.
questions.explanation: Due Process mandates strict adherence to legal and procedural requirements to guarantee transparency and legality in government contracts [81].

questions.question: Which body must approve contracts falling within the Ministerial Tenders Board (MTB) threshold?
questions.explanation: The Ministerial Tenders Board (MTB) approves procurements within the specific thresholds set for the MDA [82].

questions.question: The Accounting Officer (Permanent Secretary/CEO) chairs which committee responsible for ensuring procurement alignment with the budget and needs?
questions.explanation: The Accounting Officer chairs the Procurement Planning Committee (PPC) established in every MDA (Section 21) [83, 84].

questions.question: Who is the officer responsible for ensuring compliance with procurement thresholds and the Public Procurement Act?
questions.explanation: The Procurement Officer ensures compliance with procurement thresholds in line with the Public Procurement Act [85].

questions.question: The Public Procurement Act prohibits the practice of illegally breaking down a contract into smaller units to circumvent approval limits. This practice is known as:
questions.explanation: Contract Splitting is explicitly prohibited (Section 16 and Section 58(4)) as it undermines transparency and circumvents established thresholds [86, 87].

questions.question: An officer involved in procurement fraud, such as collusion or over-invoicing, faces which penalty?
questions.explanation: Officers involved in procurement abuse and fraud face dismissal or criminal charges (Section 58), as this constitutes serious misconduct [87, 88].

questions.question: Which authority approves emergency procurements, subject to later audit and ratification?
options: The Head of Civil Service of the Federation.
questions.explanation: The Minister authorizes emergency procurements, often in line with procurement laws and thresholds, subject to later review [89].

questions.question: The PPA mandates that the opening of bids for all competitive tenders must be conducted:
options: At the end of the contract period.
questions.explanation: Bid opening must be conducted publicly to ensure transparency and fairness (Section 27) [90, 91].

questions.question: The Bureau of Public Procurement (BPP) is established under which section of the PPA 2007?
questions.explanation: Section 3 of the PPA 2007 establishes the Bureau of Public Procurement (BPP) [92].

questions.question: Which section empowers the BPP to issue a 'Certificate of No Objection' before a contract award can be finalized?
questions.explanation: Section 5 mandates BPP to issue a 'Certificate of No Objection' for high-value procurements [93, 94].

questions.question: The minimum time frame required for submission of bids under national competitive bidding is:
questions.explanation: Section 25 requires at least 4 weeks for submission of bids under national competitive bidding [95].

questions.question: The essential administrative procedure principle that ensures capability and eligibility is assessed before the formal submission of competitive bids is:
questions.explanation: Section 22 provides for pre-qualification of bidders to ensure capability and eligibility before submission [96].

questions.question: Which section mandates that evaluation of bids must be based strictly on criteria stated in the solicitation documents?
questions.explanation: Section 33 mandates that evaluation of bids must be based strictly on criteria stated in solicitation documents [97].

questions.question: The award of a contract following evaluation is required by Section 33 to be granted to the:
options: Bidder with the highest technical score.
Bidder who offers the largest discount.
questions.explanation: Section 33 requires awarding the contract to the lowest evaluated responsive bid [98].

questions.question: Which section allows for the cancellation of a procurement proceeding at any time before the contract award?
questions.explanation: Section 31 provides that procurement proceedings may be cancelled at any time before contract award if necessary [99].

questions.question: All procurements above certain thresholds must be advertised publicly, as stipulated by:
questions.explanation: Section 23 requires advertisement of all procurements above the set thresholds in national newspapers [100, 101].

questions.question: Which section requires the publication of contract awards above certain thresholds to ensure transparency?
questions.explanation: Section 32 requires publication of contract awards above thresholds to ensure transparency and public access to records [102, 103].

questions.question: Which section promotes efficiency and transparency in procurement by providing for the use of e-procurement systems?
questions.explanation: Section 38 provides for the use of e-procurement systems in public procurement [104, 105].

questions.question: Section 57 of the PPA strictly prohibits which practice among procurement officials?
questions.explanation: Section 57 prohibits conflict of interest and mandates disclosure of potential conflicts by officials [106, 107].

questions.question: Which section prescribes imprisonment and fines for procurement-related fraud, misrepresentation, and bid-rigging?
questions.explanation: Section 58 prescribes penalties for fraud, misrepresentation, and bid-rigging, including imprisonment [108-110].

questions.question: The BPP is empowered to suspend procurement proceedings if irregularities are detected, as stipulated in:
questions.explanation: Section 53 empowers the BPP to suspend procurement if irregularities are detected [111].

questions.question: Section 16 of the PPA requires eligible contractors to demonstrate that they are currently not:
questions.explanation: Section 16 states that eligible contractors must not be in receivership, bankruptcy, or insolvency [112].

questions.question: Procurement of goods and works is prohibited without:
options: Approved budgetary provision and availability of funds.
questions.explanation: Section 14 prohibits procurement without approved budgetary provision and availability of funds [71, 113].

questions.question: The primary objective of pre-qualification of bidders in the public procurement process is:
options: To ensure capability and eligibility before submission of bids.
To reduce the number of potential contractors drastically.
To bypass the Ministerial Tenders Board.
questions.explanation: Pre-qualification is intended to determine the bidders' technical and professional capacity before receiving main tenders [96, 114].

questions.question: Which body is established by the Public Procurement Act to oversee procurement in Nigeria?
questions.explanation: The Bureau of Public Procurement (BPP) is established under the Act as the regulatory authority for procurement [115].

questions.question: Which section empowers the BPP to inspect procurement documents and records of entities?
questions.explanation: Section 5 empowers the BPP to inspect procurement records to ensure compliance [94].

questions.question: Procurement audits by the BPP are covered under which section of the PPA?
questions.explanation: Section 6 empowers BPP to conduct procurement audits [116].

questions.question: Which section stipulates the mandatory contents of standard bidding documents?
questions.explanation: Section 25 requires procuring entities to use standard bidding documents containing clear specifications and criteria [95].

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of holding a public bid opening ceremony?
options: To announce bid prices and ensure transparency.
questions.explanation: Bid opening ensures transparency by publicly announcing bid prices and bidders' names [117].

questions.question: Which section prohibits the alteration of procurement documents once bids have been opened?
questions.explanation: Section 33 prohibits alteration of procurement documents once bids have been opened [99].

questions.question: Which section empowers the BPP to blacklist or debar contractors found guilty of misconduct?
questions.explanation: Section 57 empowers the BPP to blacklist or debar contractors found guilty of misconduct [118].

questions.question: Section 16 of the PPA requires bidders to demonstrate they have fulfilled obligations regarding:
options: Taxes, pensions, and social security contributions.
questions.explanation: Section 16 requires bidders to have fulfilled obligations regarding taxes, pensions, and social security contributions [75].

questions.question: Which section provides guidelines for proper contract implementation and monitoring by procuring entities?
questions.explanation: Section 35 provides guidelines for proper contract implementation and monitoring by procuring entities [113, 119].

questions.question: Which method is allowed under the PPA when goods or services are available only from a limited number of suppliers?
questions.explanation: Section 40 allows Restricted Tendering when goods or services are available only from a limited number of suppliers [120].

questions.question: Direct Procurement, under Section 42, is typically allowed only under which circumstances?
questions.explanation: Direct Procurement (Section 42) is allowed in emergencies where competitive bidding is impractical or delay would be detrimental [121, 122].

questions.question: Section 14 of the PPA prohibits procurement without:
questions.explanation: Section 14 prohibits procurement without appropriation and funds in place [123].

questions.question: Which section of the PPA permits negotiations only under limited circumstances, such as single-source procurement?
questions.explanation: Section 36 permits negotiations only under limited circumstances, such as single-source procurement [124].

questions.question: Procedures for procuring consultant services, including selection and negotiation, are provided under which section of the PPA?
questions.explanation: Section 43 provides procedures for procuring consultant services, including selection and negotiation [125].

questions.question: Which section allows for the engagement of procurement consultants to assist procuring entities?
questions.explanation: Section 45 provides for the engagement of procurement consultants to assist procuring entities [126].

questions.question: Which body must approve the release of funds for emergency procurements, subject to later audit and ratification?
options: The Head of Civil Service of the Federation.
questions.explanation: The Minister authorizes emergency procurements, often in line with procurement laws and thresholds, subject to later review [89].

questions.question: Which section empowers the BPP to blacklist contractors for procurement misconduct?
questions.explanation: Section 57 empowers the BPP to blacklist or debar contractors found guilty of misconduct [118].

subcategories.name: Audits & Sanctions
subcategories.description: Internal audits, external audits, audit queries, financial misconduct, and disciplinary procedures

questions.question: The term **Audit Trail** refers to the sequential documentation of financial transactions to ensure:
options: Integrity and traceability, thereby ensuring accountability and transparency.
questions.explanation: Audit Trail refers to the sequential documentation of transactions to ensure integrity, traceability, accountability, and transparency [91, 127].

questions.question: The type of internal control function that involves checking financial commitment before funds are paid, confirming legality and budgetary provision, is known as:
questions.explanation: Pre-audit functions involve checks before financial commitment is finalized to confirm legality and budgetary provision [128, 129].

questions.question: The loss of government funds or property must be communicated immediately to:
options: The Head of the Civil Service and the Minister of Justice.
The Auditor-General of the Federation and the Accountant-General of the Federation.
The Minister of Finance and the National Assembly.
The officer's immediate supervisor and the Head of Accounts.
questions.explanation: Loss of government funds or property must be communicated immediately to the Auditor-General and the Accountant-General [129].

questions.question: The maximum penalty for financial misconduct or fraud under the Financial Regulations may include:
questions.explanation: Public officers guilty of financial misconduct may face disciplinary action or prosecution, including surcharge and dismissal [130].

questions.question: The primary anti-corruption agency responsible for investigating and prosecuting financial crimes like fraud and money laundering is the:
questions.explanation: The Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC) investigates and prosecutes financial crimes, fraud, and money laundering [131, 132].

questions.question: Which body monitors compliance with anti-corruption laws, focuses on institutional corruption, and enforces ethical standards in public finance?
questions.explanation: The Independent Corrupt Practices Commission (ICPC) focuses on institutional corruption and enforcement of ethical standards [133].

questions.question: Dismissal of an officer for serious financial misconduct must be supported by:
options: A direct memo from the Minister.
A Board of Inquiry report and internal investigation findings.
questions.explanation: Dismissal for financial misconduct must be supported by internal audit investigation findings and often requires a Board of Inquiry following due process [134].

questions.question: The concept of organizing financial tasks such that no single individual controls all stages of a transaction, thereby preventing fraud, is known as:
questions.explanation: Segregation of Duties is a crucial internal control mechanism designed to prevent fraud by distributing control over financial operations [135, 136].

questions.question: Which concept describes mechanisms put in place to trace financial transactions and detect irregularities?
questions.explanation: The Audit Trail documents the flow of transactions, and the Internal Audit monitors compliance to detect irregularities [127].

questions.question: The penalty for unauthorized expenditure, known as **Excess Vote**, is typically identified through:
options: The Auditor-General's Report on public accounts.
questions.explanation: The Auditor-General reports on all unauthorized or excess expenditure in their report on public accounts [137].

questions.question: The use of government funds beyond the budget without subsequent legislative approval is classified as:
questions.explanation: Unauthorized expenditure is categorized as misappropriation or unauthorized spending [138].

questions.question: The final authority to restore a deferred increment, which requires assessing service improvement and conduct, lies with the:
questions.explanation: The Permanent Secretary/Head of Extra-Ministerial Office holds the authority to decide on restoring a deferred increment (Rule 040208) [139, 140].

questions.question: If an officer causes financial loss, the penalty imposed (surcharge) is intended to recover:
options: The exact amount of financial loss caused by the officer's fault.
A fixed statutory amount unrelated to the loss.
questions.explanation: Surcharge is the recovery of government losses from the officer's pay, applied when the loss is due to the officer‚Äôs fault [141].

questions.question: Which of the following bodies is empowered to grant special increments to an officer whose increment was previously withheld?
options: The National Salaries, Incomes and Wages Commission (NSIWC).
The Permanent Secretary/Head of Extra-Ministerial Office.
questions.explanation: The Federal Civil Service Commission (FCSC) is the body empowered to grant special increments [61, 77].

questions.question: The ultimate disciplinary penalty for serious misconduct, such as fraud or corruption, resulting in the forfeiture of all claims to retirement benefits, is:
questions.explanation: The ultimate penalty for serious misconduct is dismissal, resulting in the forfeiture of benefits, subject to the Pension Reform Act (Rule 100407) [142-144].

questions.question: Which officer's responsibility includes advising the Accounting Officer on the adequacy and functioning of the internal controls within the MDA?
questions.explanation: The Head of Internal Audit is responsible for independently evaluating financial activities and controls and advising the Accounting Officer [144].

questions.question: The purpose of activating an **Audit Alarm** is to necessitate:
options: A detailed investigation into the suspected irregularity.
Automatic transfer of the implicated officer.
The suspension of all staff salary payments.
questions.explanation: An Audit Alarm necessitates a detailed investigation into the suspected irregularity flagged immediately [145].

questions.question: The term **'Accruals'** in government financial reporting refers to:
options: Cash received in advance for services.
Expenses or revenues recognized when incurred, not when cash is exchanged.
Budgetary reserves held by the Minister of Finance.
Penalties imposed for late payment of taxes.
questions.explanation: Accruals refer to expenses or revenues recognized when incurred, not when cash changes hands [146].

questions.question: Which type of audit, mandated under the PPA, involves the review of a bidder's documentation to confirm eligibility after the bid opening?
questions.explanation: Post-Qualification audit is the review of bidder‚Äôs documentation to confirm eligibility after bid opening [147].

questions.question: What is the penalty for an officer who fails the compulsory confirmation examination after three consecutive attempts?
options: Required to resign or be withdrawn from the service.
Suspension until they pass the exam.
questions.explanation: An Officer who fails the confirmation examination after three consecutive attempts shall be required to resign or be withdrawn from the service (Rule 030104) [148].

questions.question: Which agency is responsible for enforcing ethical standards in public office, particularly by receiving and verifying public officers‚Äô asset declarations?
options: The Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC).
questions.explanation: The Code of Conduct Bureau (CCB) receives asset declarations and monitors compliance with ethical standards [149, 150].

questions.question: When issuing an Audit Query (FR 1204), the Accounting Officer must address the formal response to:
questions.explanation: The Audit Query is a formal question from auditors, and the response must be addressed back to the originating authority (the issuing Auditor) for resolution [151].

questions.question: The Auditor-General's Report primarily focuses on the review of:
questions.explanation: The Audit Report focuses on the review of public accounts (past expenditure and revenue) and is critical for legislative oversight [152].

questions.question: To whom must an Officer promptly report a criminal charge or the outcome of such charge, under disciplinary action, whenever such event occurs?
options: His Permanent Secretary/Head of Extra-Ministerial Office.
The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation.
questions.explanation: An Officer must promptly report a criminal charge or the outcome of such charge to his Permanent Secretary/Head of Extra-Ministerial Office (Rule 100409) [153, 154].

questions.question: The disciplinary authority responsible for exercising control over Officers in the Federal Civil Service (GL 07 and above) is vested in the:
options: Head of the Civil Service of the Federation (OHCSF)
questions.explanation: The power to dismiss and to exercise disciplinary control over Officers in the Federal Civil Service is vested in the Federal Civil Service Commission (Rule 100102) [155].

questions.question: Which specific body has delegated full disciplinary powers to Permanent Secretaries/Heads of Extra-Ministerial Offices in respect of officers on Salary GL 13 and below?
options: The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation
questions.explanation: The FCSC delegates disciplinary powers to Permanent Secretaries/Heads of Extra-Ministerial Offices for officers on GL 13 and below [156-158].

questions.question: If the FCSC does not approve the Officer's dismissal or impose any penalty, the Officer shall be reinstated forthwith and be entitled to the full amount of salary denied him if he was interdicted or suspended, as stipulated by:
questions.explanation: If the Commission does not approve the Officer‚Äôs dismissal, he shall be reinstated forthwith and be entitled to the full amount of salary denied him if he was interdicted or suspended (Rule 100307(xi)) [159, 160].

questions.question: Which of the following acts constitutes **Gross Misconduct** under the Civil Service Handbook?
questions.explanation: Fraud and falsification of records constitute gross misconduct in the civil service [159, 161].

questions.question: The misconduct described as absenteeism without official permission is classified as:
questions.explanation: Absenteeism without permission is classified as gross misconduct [162, 163].

questions.question: Which committee's recommendation forms the basis for the discipline (including removal from office) of officers on Salary GL 06 and below by the Permanent Secretary/Head of Extra-Ministerial Office?
questions.explanation: Discipline and removal of Officers on GL 06 and below is based on the recommendation of the Junior Staff Committee (JSC) (Rule 100104) [164].

questions.question: Concealment of facts or any false statement made in an application for Government employment shall be regarded as sufficient grounds for:
options: Non-engagement or subsequent termination of appointment without notice
questions.explanation: Concealment of facts or any false statement in an application for employment shall be regarded as sufficient grounds for non-engagement or subsequent termination of appointment without notice (Rule 100431) [164, 165].

questions.question: Which type of assessment report is often used as evidence of **General Inefficiency** (Rule 100201)?
questions.explanation: General inefficiency is directly linked to performance and competence, captured in performance appraisals (Chapter 5) [166].

questions.question: Before documentary evidence can be used against an officer during an inquiry (Rule 100307(vii)), the officer must previously have been provided with a copy thereof or given:
questions.explanation: No documentary evidence shall be used against the Officer unless he has previously been supplied with a copy thereof or given open access thereto (Rule 100307(vii)) [160, 167].

questions.question: The ultimate penalty for serious misconduct, resulting in the forfeiture of all claims to retirement benefits, leave, or transport grant, is subject to the provisions of the:
questions.explanation: Dismissal results in forfeiture subject to the provisions of the Pension Reform Act, 2014 (as amended) (Rule 100407) [142, 143].

questions.question: The disciplinary process starts with a formal query issued by which officer?
questions.explanation: The disciplinary process starts with a query issued by the supervisor or Head of Department (Rule 100307(i)) [168, 169].

questions.question: An officer involved in procurement fraud, such as collusion or over-invoicing, faces which penalty under the Public Procurement Act (PPA) framework (Section 58)?
options: Dismissal or criminal charges (imprisonment and fines)
questions.explanation: Section 58 prescribes imprisonment and fines for procurement-related fraud, which constitutes gross misconduct leading to dismissal [109, 168].

questions.question: Which of the following disciplinary penalties is generally **prohibited** under the Financial Regulations (FR 3401)?
questions.explanation: Disciplinary penalties may include surcharges, reductions, or warnings, but imposing monetary fines on officers as a penalty is generally prohibited [170].

questions.question: The expression 'serious financial embarrassment' (Rule 100414) refers to an officer's state of indebtedness which has actually caused serious financial hardship to him and which may be prejudicial to:
options: The general meaning of the said expression.
The ability of the government to pay him.
questions.explanation: Serious financial embarrassment relates to indebtedness causing hardship prejudicial to the general meaning of the expression (Rule 100414) [104, 171].

questions.question: If an officer is suspected of **General Inefficiency**, the superior officer must first administer instruction and warning, and give the officer adequate time to redeem his image, for the objective of improving the officer's:
questions.explanation: The objective is to improve the officer's usefulness and efficiency (Rule 100201 practice) [168].

questions.question: The minimum period for which an increment deferment must be fixed is:
questions.explanation: If an increment is deferred, the period must be fixed for not less than six months (Rule 040205) [42].

questions.question: Which of the following disciplinary measures can be taken against a Permanent Secretary found guilty of misconduct (Rule 100702)?
questions.explanation: Disciplinary measures against a Permanent Secretary include dismissal, termination, or retirement (Rule 100702) [157].

questions.question: An officer, upon resumption from casual or special leave within the country, provided he spends such leave in Nigeria, is NOT required to have whom appointed to act in the duty post in question?
questions.explanation: An acting Officer will not be regarded as relinquishing the duties and responsibilities of his acting appointment by proceeding on casual or special leave within the country, and it is not necessary during any such leave to appoint another Officer to act in the duty post in question (Rule 020708(a)) [172].

questions.question: The dismissal of Officers on GL 06 and below requires the ultimate approval of which body, despite the involvement of the Junior Staff Committee (JSC)?
questions.explanation: The dismissal of Officers on GL 06 and below is an exception to the delegated powers and still requires the approval of the FCSC (Rule 100103) [173].

questions.question: If an officer resigns from the Service, they will forfeit all claims to vacation leave, and any leave privileges granted will be:
questions.explanation: An Officer who resigns will forfeit claims to vacation leave, and any leave privileges granted will be ex-gratia (Rule 020904(i)) [174].

questions.question: Accepting paid employment during a period of Leave of Absence without the express approval of the OHCSF may lead to which disciplinary consequence?
questions.explanation: Accepting paid employment without approval (Rule 100429) constitutes misconduct and can lead to severe disciplinary action, including dismissal [165, 175].

questions.question: Which of the following is considered 'serious misconduct' under the PSR (Rule 100402)?
questions.explanation: Falsification of records is listed explicitly as an act of serious misconduct (Rule 100402(a)) [176].

questions.question: In the case of an inquiry into serious misconduct, the head of the officer‚Äôs department shall generally **not** be a member of the inquiry board, in order to maintain:
questions.explanation: The head of the officer's department shall not be a member of the board (Rule 100307(v)) to ensure impartiality in the disciplinary process [160, 177].

questions.question: An officer convicted of a criminal offence (other than a minor traffic or sanitary offence) shall be placed under suspension with effect from the date of conviction, pending determination of his case by the Commission, as per:
questions.explanation: An officer convicted of a criminal offence shall be suspended pending the Commission's determination (Rule 100412) [178].

questions.question: An officer absent from duty without leave (Rule 100413) renders himself liable to be dismissed from the Service, and the onus rests entirely on him to show that circumstances do not justify the imposition of the full penalty, due to the concept of:
questions.explanation: Absence without leave where the onus rests on the officer to justify the absence implies desertion or serious misconduct (Rule 100413) [178].

questions.question: What is the penalty for unauthorized absence from duty?
options: Loss of pay for the period of absence.
questions.explanation: Unauthorized absence from duty results in loss of pay for the period of absence (Rule 040206) [47, 152].

subcategories.name: General Financial Management
subcategories.description: TSA, revenue management, financial statements, reconciliations, and other general topics

questions.question: Who is designated as the Chief Accounting Officer personally responsible for the control, custody, and disbursement of funds within a Ministry or Extra-Ministerial Department (MDA)?
questions.explanation: The Permanent Secretary is the Chief Accounting Officer of a Ministry, personally responsible for all financial operations and integrity [19, 20].

questions.question: Which government official is responsible for issuing **Treasury Circulars** that provide detailed instructions on financial procedures and implementation across MDAs?
questions.explanation: The Accountant-General of the Federation issues Treasury Circulars to guide accounting officers on procedures [179-181].

questions.question: Which officer is primarily responsible for maintaining the departmental **Vote Book** to monitor budgetary allocations and expenditures against commitments?
questions.explanation: The Vote Controller maintains the Vote Book (or departmental vote ledger) to monitor budgetary allocations and expenditures [16, 17, 181].

questions.question: The main purpose of the **Cash Book** is:
options: To monitor inflow and outflow of cash
questions.explanation: The Cash Book is used to record all inflows and outflows of cash, supporting reconciliation and control [182].

questions.question: Which agency is responsible for managing Nigeria‚Äôs public debt, covering both domestic and external obligations?
questions.explanation: The Debt Management Office (DMO) is responsible for managing Nigeria‚Äôs public debt [183].

questions.question: What does **TSA** stand for in Nigeria‚Äôs financial system?
questions.explanation: TSA stands for Treasury Single Account, which consolidates government revenues into a single account for transparency [184].

questions.question: Which law provides the legal framework for prudent management of public finances in Nigeria?
questions.explanation: The Fiscal Responsibility Act provides the legal framework for prudent management of public finances in Nigeria [185].

questions.question: Who authorizes payments from the Consolidated Revenue Fund (CRF)?
questions.explanation: Payments from the Consolidated Revenue Fund must be authorized by the National Assembly [56, 186].

questions.question: Which document accompanies all payments made in Ministries, detailing the expenditure and authorization?
questions.explanation: All government payments must be backed by duly approved Payment Vouchers [29, 187].

questions.question: Which officer must sign all **Payment Vouchers** before payments are processed, confirming the correctness and classification of the transaction?
questions.explanation: The Head of Accounts must sign all payment vouchers before payments are processed [19, 188].

questions.question: What is the **Consolidated Revenue Fund**?
options: Main account into which all government revenues are paid
questions.explanation: The Consolidated Revenue Fund (CRF) is the main account into which all government revenues are paid [189].

questions.question: Who is responsible for ensuring that all government revenue is remitted into the Treasury Single Account (TSA)?
questions.explanation: The Accountant-General ensures that all revenues are remitted into the Treasury Single Account [190].

questions.question: Which specific Nigerian legal instrument established the Office of the Auditor-General for the Federation (AuGF)?
questions.explanation: The 1999 Constitution of Nigeria established the Office of the Auditor-General for the Federation [191].

questions.question: What is the purpose of issuing a **Treasury Receipt**?
questions.explanation: A Treasury Receipt is issued to acknowledge payments made into government coffers (revenue collection) [192].

questions.question: Which government fund is statutorily established to meet unforeseen and urgent government expenditures?
questions.explanation: The Contingencies Fund is used to meet unforeseen and urgent government expenditures [53-55].

questions.question: What is the meaning of **'public expenditure'**?
options: All government spending from public funds
questions.explanation: Public expenditure includes all government spending from public funds on recurrent and capital projects [193].

questions.question: What does **'Recurrent Expenditure'** include?
questions.explanation: Recurrent Expenditure covers spending that is regular and occurs within the fiscal year, such as salaries and overhead costs [194].

questions.question: The **Contingency Fund** is reserved for which type of expenditure?
questions.explanation: The Contingency Fund is reserved for emergency and unforeseen government expenditures [54, 194].
questions.chapter: General Financial Management ‚Äì Contingency Fund Purpose

questions.question: Who is the principal signatory to government bank accounts?
questions.explanation: The Accountant-General is the principal signatory to government bank accounts, controlling federal receipts and payments [195].

questions.question: Which officer is responsible for certifying that services have been duly performed before payment is made to a vendor?
questions.explanation: The Head of Department certifies that services have been duly performed before payments are made [30, 31].

questions.question: What does the term **'accruals'** mean in government financial reporting?
options: Cash received in advance for services.
Expenses or revenues recognized when incurred, not when cash is exchanged.
Budgetary reserves held by the Minister of Finance.
Penalties imposed for late payment of taxes.
questions.explanation: Accruals refer to expenses or revenues recognized when incurred, not when cash changes hands [146, 196].

questions.question: Which agency regulates Nigeria‚Äôs capital market?
questions.explanation: The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) regulates Nigeria‚Äôs capital market [196].

questions.question: What does **IGR** stand for in public finance?
questions.explanation: IGR stands for Internally Generated Revenue, which refers to income generated by states or ministries apart from federal allocations [197].

questions.question: Who is responsible for issuing receipts for government revenue upon collection?
questions.explanation: Revenue Collectors are responsible for issuing receipts for all government revenues received [198].

questions.question: Which specific account holds all federal revenues before distribution among the three tiers of government?
questions.explanation: The Federation Account holds revenues before distribution among the three tiers of government [199].

questions.question: Which account is historically used for financing capital projects in Nigeria?
questions.explanation: The Development Fund is used for financing capital projects in Nigeria [200].

questions.question: Which dedicated account is used for repayment of Nigeria‚Äôs external and domestic debts?
questions.explanation: The Debt Service Account is used for repayment of Nigeria‚Äôs external and domestic debts [201].

questions.question: Which Nigerian law established the Debt Management Office (DMO)?
questions.explanation: The Debt Management Office was established by the Debt Management Act 2003 [202].

questions.question: What is the primary responsibility of the **Treasury** in Nigeria?
options: To manage government cash flow and payments
questions.explanation: The Treasury manages government cash flows, payments, and receipts [203].

questions.question: What is the primary role of the **Accountant-General of the Federation**?
options: To manage and control all receipts and payments of the federal government
questions.explanation: The Accountant-General manages and controls all receipts and payments of the federal government [204].
questions.chapter: General Financial Management ‚Äì AGF Primary Role

questions.question: Which Nigerian agency regulates and supervises banks?
questions.explanation: The Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) regulates and supervises banks in Nigeria [205].

questions.question: What is the main source of Nigeria‚Äôs Federation Account revenue?
questions.explanation: Oil revenue remains the primary source of Nigeria‚Äôs Federation Account revenue [206].

questions.question: What is the main source of Local Government revenue?
questions.explanation: The main source of Local Government revenue is allocations from the Federation Account [207].

questions.question: What is the primary function of the Fiscal Responsibility Act?
options: To promote transparency in public finance
questions.explanation: The Fiscal Responsibility Act promotes transparency, accountability, and prudence in the management of public finance [208].

questions.question: Which financial instrument is issued by the Federal Government to raise short-term funds in the money market?
questions.explanation: Treasury Bills are short-term instruments issued by government to raise funds [209].

questions.question: Which officer is responsible for preparing and maintaining the departmental **vote ledger**?
questions.explanation: The Vote Controller maintains the departmental vote ledger [210, 211].

questions.question: Which officer is responsible for preparing bank reconciliation statements monthly?
questions.explanation: The Accounts Officer is responsible for preparing bank reconciliation statements [212].

questions.question: What is the main purpose of a **Bank Reconciliation Statement**?
options: To reconcile differences between Cash Book and Bank Statement
questions.explanation: A Bank Reconciliation Statement reconciles differences between the Cash Book and the Bank Statement [213].

questions.question: Which officer is responsible for maintaining the General Ledger for the entire Federal Government?
questions.explanation: The Accountant-General of the Federation is responsible for maintaining the General Ledger [214].

questions.question: Which officer certifies that funds are available in the budget before any expenditure or commitment is incurred?
questions.explanation: The Vote Controller certifies that funds are available before incurring expenditure [215, 216].

questions.question: Which officer is statutorily designated as the Chief Financial Adviser to the Federal Government?
questions.explanation: The Minister of Finance is the Chief Financial Adviser to the Federal Government [41, 217].

questions.question: Which fund is established specifically for the replacement of depreciating government assets?
questions.explanation: The Replacement Reserve Fund is used for replacing depreciating government assets [39-41].

questions.question: What must **'public revenue'** include?
options: All government income including taxes, oil, and non-oil sources
questions.explanation: Public revenue includes all government income, such as taxes, oil, customs, levies, and other sources [218].

questions.question: What is the meaning of **'Capital Expenditure'** in financial terms?
options: Spending on acquiring or maintaining fixed assets.
questions.explanation: Capital Expenditure is spending on assets and infrastructure that create future benefits [15, 48, 211].

questions.question: The **Government Integrated Financial Management Information System (GIFMIS)** is primarily designed to integrate:
options: All MDA financial operations, accounting, and expenditure tracking.
questions.explanation: GIFMIS supports integrated financial operations, accounting, and expenditure tracking across MDAs [49].

questions.question: The total amount of funds allocated for staff salaries (Personnel Emoluments) in the budget is controlled primarily by data sourced from which platform?
questions.explanation: The Integrated Personnel and Payroll Information System (IPPIS) holds the accurate data on staff nominal roll, grade levels, and steps, which determines personnel emoluments [34-36].
questions.chapter: General Financial Management ‚Äì Personnel Cost Control

questions.question: Which officer prepares Nigeria‚Äôs annual budget performance reports for review?
questions.explanation: The Budget Officer prepares annual budget performance reports for review [52].

questions.question: Which document is used to request for the release of funds from the Treasury to the MDAs?
questions.explanation: A Warrant provides for the release of funds for both capital and recurrent expenditures [8].

questions.question: Which officer is responsible for certifying stock balances in government stores periodically?
questions.explanation: The Store Officer certifies stock balances in government stores periodically [219].

questions.question: Which officer is responsible for certifying the physical existence and accuracy of stores received or periodically verifying stock balances in government stores?
questions.explanation: The Store Officer is explicitly tasked with certifying the accuracy of stores received and certifying stock balances in government stores periodically, a fundamental aspect of inventory control and fraud prevention [1].
